Manirul Islam Writing – review & editing Supervision Methodology Funding acquisition Conceptualization a ⁎ a Department of Chemistry, University of Kalyani, Kalyani, Nadia 741235, W.B., India Department of Chemistry University of Kalyani, Kalyani Nadia W.B. 741235 India aDepartment of Chemistry, University of Kalyani, Kalyani, Nadia 741235, W.B., India b Department of Pharmacognosy, College of Pharmacy, King Saud University, Riyadh 11451, Saudi Arabia Department of Pharmacognosy College of Pharmacy King Saud University Riyadh 11451 Saudi Arabia bDepartment of Pharmacognosy, King Saud University, Riyadh 11451, Saudi Arabia ⁎ Corresponding author. Our study presents a novel synthetic approach for the visible-light-assisted photocatalytic production of 2-hydroxybenzaldehyde from phenol via CO2 reduction, using copper nanoparticles (Cu NPs)-incorporated two-dimensional covalent organic framework (TR-PDA COF) photocatalyst. The Cu@TR-PDA catalyst exhibited a low band gap energy (2.14 eV), enabling efficient visible light absorption and photocatalytic activity. Under optimized conditions, this catalyst achieved 87 % conversion of phenol to 2-hydroxybenzaldehyde under 20 W white LED light. The reaction was light-dependent and required a base. Mechanistic studies revealed that formaldehyde (HCHO), generated from CO2 photoreduction, served as a key intermediate, which reacted with phenol to form the desired product. Furthermore, the Cu@TR-PDA catalyst demonstrated excellent reusability over six cycles, and showed minimal metal leaching, confirming its heterogeneous nature. This work offers a promising strategy for the sustainable conversion of CO2 into valuable chemicals using a metal-based photocatalyst under visible light. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Covalent organic framework Nanoparticles Carbon dioxide reduction 2-hydroxybenzaldehyde Photocatalysis Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The demand for energy among human beings has been increased along with the economic development of the world society. Presently, approximately 80 % of the energy utilized globally is generated from fossil fuels that include coal, natural gas, and oil [1]. It is crucial to remember that an extreme use of fossil fuels has caused an energy shortage and also the ecosystem has been negatively impacted by the emitted serious greenhouse gas CO2 [2–4]. Beside this, the average world temperature would rise due to uncontrollable increase in the concentration of atmospheric CO2 levels (above 400 ppm) [5], which would cause the melting of polar ice, an increase in ocean water levels, the shrinkage of islands, the desert spreading out, and perhaps even the extinction of some species. Finding effective strategies to successfully address the problems of the energy dilemma as well as earth pollution is currently a global struggle. In this scenario, one of the most significant solutions is to develop greener, environmentally sustainable, and economically advantageous techniques of capturing and storing CO2, as well as transforming the gases into essential compounds with high commercial value [6,7]. The extraordinarily stable structure of linear CO2 molecule requires a massive energy intake for the dissociation (bond dissociation energy = 187 kcal/mol) of the comparably shorter CO bond (bond length=1.16 Å) [8,9]. Due to its structural feature, thermodynamic stability (ΔGf ° = −394.36 kJ/mol), and high activation energy requirements, the chemical route of CO2 conversion is challenging [10–12]. As a renewable C1 feedstock, the usage of CO2 is tremendously important, since it is highly attractive, non-flammable, abundant, non-toxic, cheap, and sustainable [13–15]. The application of renewable, inexpensive and ubiquitous solar energy for the photocatalytic CO2 reduction in this regard is particularly intriguing as a substitute sustainable strategy [16–19]. One of the most often employed transformations in chemical synthesis is the formylation (-CHO) of compounds containing hydroxy groups (-OH). There are numerous synthetic techniques for formylation of the phenol into 2-hydroxybenzaldehydes. A large variety of commercial and therapeutic compounds have been produced using this essential building components 2-hydroxybenzaldehydes. Most commonly, salicylaldehyde is used to make the important medicinal substances such as coumarin and aspirin [20,21]. This aromatic organic compound serves as preservative in cosmetic items including perfume, dye, essential oil etc. and employs for identify ketonuria in medical science [20]. Traditionally, to produce 2-hydroxybenzaldehyde in pure form, Reimer–Tiemann reaction process is involved [22]. The downside of this approach is that this process takes a long time, uses more energy, and yields a lower amount of product [23]. 2-hydroxybenzaldehyde and their derivatives belong to an important class of synthetic compounds with significant industrial applications. As a consequence, there has been an increase of attention in this research field to explore the novel ways of producing these compounds. In addition, Casiraghi and co-workers demonstrated the SnCl4 catalysed synthesis of 2-hydroxybenzaldehyde through the reaction of phenol and formaldehyde at 100 °C [24]. Also, Hansen et al. exhibited 2-hydroxybenzaldehyde from phenol in presence of MgCl2–Et3N base [25]. The challenging and intriguing method used in current research to mitigate the increasing levels of greenhouse gas CO2 is the conversion of CO2 into solar fuel [26,27]. A successful and potential technique that has generated a lot of attention, is photocatalytic CO2 reduction, which employs the energy of light to stimulate a material that can activate CO2. Visible light has the advantage of being plentiful, inexpensive, and naturally occurring. It also has the advantage of facilitating photocatalytic processes under benign environmental conditions with ambient temperature and atmospheric pressure. Several photocatalysts, including metal oxides, metal organic frameworks (MOFs), sulphides, ionic liquids, Ti-containing molecular sieves, polymer semiconductors, etc. are being used in the process of CO2 conversion [28–33]. However, in CO2 transformation efficiency, the majority of these catalysts are insufficient for practical usage. Therefore, construction of innovative visible light sensitive recyclable catalysts, which can absorb adequate energy from light to generate electron–hole pairs, is crucial for successfully converting CO2 into beneficial chemicals. As recently discovered porous polymers, covalent organic frameworks (COFs) have sparked interest among scientists due to their exceptional catalytic ability. COFs, which are highly ordered organic polymers with excellent crystallinity and permanent porosity, are developed by the inclusion of certain light-weight organic building components via potent covalent linkages [34–36]. This emerging class of porous materials are classified into two-dimensional (2D) [37,38] and three-dimensional (3D) [39,40] geometries based on the dimensions of the building blocks. The extremely organized channel designs within the frameworks are a distinctive characteristic of COFs that set them apart from amorphous porous organic polymers [41]. Owing to their inherent porosity, designable structures, large surface area, low density, easy modification and functionalization, tunable light harvesting properties, CO2 uptake capacity and potential stability, COFs have drawn a lot of extensive attention for variety of purposes including catalysis [42–46], gas adsorption and storage [47–49], separation [50,51], environmental remediation [52,53], optoelectronics [54–57], sensing [58–60], electrochemistry [61,62], and drug delivery [63–65]. Additionally, covalent organic frameworks have demonstrated important properties that make most of the COFs effective photocatalysts for the CO2 reduction such as (i) high thermal and chemical stability, (ii) the good electron-transporting capacity and noticeable photoconductivity of COFs, (iii) simple recovery process and the ability to reuse the COF, (iv) the COF's conduction band energy is more negative than CO2's reduction potential which facilitate the reduction of CO2, (v) slower rate of electron–hole pair recombination [66–68]. Moreover, metal ions have drawn a lot of attention in research because they show improved catalytic activity upon incorporation into such porous surfaces. Metal nanoparticles (NPs) exhibited significant advantages over single atoms in photocatalysis due to their more efficient charge carrier separation/transfer and better light absorption [69]. When combined with COFs, metal NPs can significantly enhance catalytic efficiency. This enhancement arises from the synergistic interaction between the metal particle and support material, leading to improved interfacial charge transfer kinetics [70]. It has been reported that many metals have enhanced CO2 reduction efficiency [71–73]. Additionally, plasmonic elements (for instance, Ag, Au, Cu etc.) can alter the chemical reaction's route and enhance selectivity and kinetics [74]. The two most studied plasmonic elements are silver (Ag) and gold (Au), however their widespread application is limited due to their expensive nature [75]. In contrast, copper (Cu) is a cheap, non-noble plasmonic metal with a variety of accessible oxidation states (such as, Cu0, CuI, CuII, and CuIII), that is being considered as a potential replacement for the noble metals. Cu has a notable sensitivity to visible light through the localized surface plasmon resonance (LSPR) effect, which is caused by excitations of free-electron oscillation [76]. Due to such intriguing characteristics of Cu, it is predicted that Cu NPs-modified COF will show superior photocatalytic CO2 reduction in presence of visible light. Here, we have designed Cu@TR-PDA photocatalyst, where chemically stable TR-PDA COF acts as a support material, to demonstrate visible-light driven efficient production of 2-hydroxybenzaldehyde derivatives from phenol derivatives using CO2 as C1 source in presence of base at room temperature and atmospheric pressure. Moreover, this as-prepared heterogeneous photocatalyst is easily recoverable and recyclable, and the catalytic efficacy remains intact even after the sixth cycle of the catalytic reaction. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Synthetic procedure of Cu@TR-PDA photocatalyst Initially, the imine-linked COF (TR-PDA) was prepared by reacting Tri-formyl resorcinol (TR) and Para-phenylenediamine (PDA) via simple hydrothermal method (Supporting Information) (Scheme 1 ). Typically, 30 mL of ethanol was added to a 50 mL round-bottom flask (RB), and 100 mg of the as-synthesized TR-PDA COF was mixed and subjected to a 15 mins sonication. 5 wt % of CuCl2. 2H2O (13.4 mg) was added to the solution and fitted with a condenser for refluxing. The reflux was conducted at 60 °C for 2–3 h while vigorously stirring. Afterwards, 10 ml 1 M l-ascorbic acid was gradually added to the mixture with continuous stirring for 18 h at room temperature. After filtering and washing with ethanol to eliminate any unreacted chemicals, the resulting black-colored Cu@TR-PDA was dried in a vacuum desiccator. 2.2 General procedure for the production of 2-hydroxybenzaldehyde from phenols and CO2 using Cu@TR-PDA photocatalyst In a typical photocatalytic experiment, phenol (1 mmol), potassium tert‑butoxide (2 mmol), TEOA (1 mmol), and CH3CN solvent (10 mL) were mixed in 50 mL RB (Scheme 2 ). The RB was initially purged with N2 gas for 10–15 min to remove the air from reaction mixture. Following that, the as-formed Cu@TR-PDA photocatalyst (10 mg) was added into it and the flask was then properly closed using a septum and stirred continuously under CO2 environment for 18 h in presence of white LED (20 W). TLC method was used to monitor the progression of experiment. Upon completion of the reaction, the catalyst material was removed from the reaction mixture by filtration. The final product was examined by using 1H NMR spectroscopy in CDCl3 solvent. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization The developed Cu NPs embedded TR-PDA photocatalyst was thoroughly characterized using a variety of techniques, including powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), nitrogen Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) adsorption/desorption isotherm, field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM), high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM), thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and UV–vis spectroscopic studies. Moreover, the copper nanoparticle (Cu NPs) loading in the Cu@TR-PDA catalyst is 3.6 wt %, as determined by atomic absorption spectroscopy (AAS) analysis. Fig. 1 a demonstrates the PXRD (powder X-ray diffraction) patterns of the catalyst Cu@TR-PDA COF. The PXRD pattern shows a prominent and highly intense diffraction peak at a diffraction angle (2θ) of 4.8°, which corresponds to the (100) facet and indicates the exceptional crystalline nature of the material. In addition to the high intensity diffraction peak mentioned above, the major peaks at 8.3° and 12.6° signify the facets of (110) and (210), respectively [77]. Furthermore, a broad high intensity band at 26.8° indexed as (001) miller plane of the as-obtained catalyst due to the interlayer π-π stacking between two-dimensional (2D) layers. The d-spacing values that are obtained by utilizing Bragg's equation (nλ = 2d sin θ, where λ = 0.15406 nm and n = 1) are d100=1.84 nm, d110 =1.06 nm, d210= 0.70 nm, and d001=0.33 nm. The wide angle PXRD patterns (2θ >30°) of Cu@TR-PDA COF display peaks around 32.2°, 35.8°, and 38.9°, which correspond to the (110), (002), and (111) lattice planes of CuO (JCPDS no 80–1917) [78]. The diffraction peaks at 36.6°, 42.3°, 61.6°, and 73.5° imply the corresponding (111), (200), (220) and (311) plane of cubic phase Cu2O (JCPDS no 78–2076) [79]. The peaks at 50.4° and 74.2° can be attributed to the (200) and (220) facets for the Cu (JCPDS no 04–0836) [80]. Fig. 1b displays the FTIR (Fourier-transform infrared) spectra of the starting monomer units TR and PDA, TR-PDA COF, and Cu@TR-PDA catalyst, confirming the existence of functional groups in all of the materials. The FT-IR spectra of TR exhibit strong absorption peaks at 1592 cm−1 and 1643 cm−1, respectively, which are ascribed to the presence of -(CC) and carbonyl -(CO) stretching bands. In PDA, the absorption band of primary amines located at around 3375–3200 cm−1. The band at 1574 cm−1 in the TR-PDA COF attributed to -(CN) stretching, along with a peak at 1239 cm−1 originated from the β-keto enamine's -(CN) stretching vibration [81]. Compared to the aldehyde group of the TR (1643 cm−1), the -(CO) stretching frequency band at 1621 cm−1 has broadened, indicating the tautomerism of the COF framework structure. The other characteristic absorption peaks at 3413 cm−1 (enolic -OH), 1574 cm−1 (-CN), and 1462 cm−1 (-CC) ensure the presence of both keto and enol form in the TR-PDA COF in solid state. Furthermore, after copper loading to the TR-PDA COF, all of the parent framework's peaks are intact in the FTIR spectra of the Cu@TR-PDA catalyst, indicating the structural stability of the COF. Fig. 2 depicts the N2 Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) adsorption/desorption isotherm and the pore-size distribution (inset) of the π-bonded stacked Cu@TR-PDA catalyst. In accordance with the IUPAC physical adsorption isotherm, the as-prepared Cu@TR-PDA COF exhibits the type IV isotherm with an H3 type hysteresis loop in the P/P0 range 0.1–0.9 [82,83]. The above investigation showed that the BET surface area and total pore volume of Cu NPs loaded TR-PDA COF are 241 m2 g −1 and 0.113 cm3 g −1, respectively. The distribution of pore size, derived from the adsorption data of the isotherm, suggests the existence of mesoporous voids with pore diameter of 4.6 nm. The nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherm of the TR-PDA COF reveals a marginally greater surface area about 309 m2 g −1 compared to the copper-loaded material and the pore diameter observed from PSD plot (Fig. S1, Supporting Information) is 4.3 nm. The microscopic study reveals the morphological structure of the TR-PDA and Cu@TR-PDA catalyst. As shown from the images of field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM) analysis, the Cu@TR-PDA material (Fig. 3 a) features irregular porous-like structure. Fig. S2 (Supporting Information), also represents the SEM images of TR-PDA COF. Beside this, to learn more regarding the internal morphology, layer planarity and interlayer stacking of the as-formed material, high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) study is required. Fig. 3b illustrates the HRTEM images of the Cu@TR-PDA catalyst at various magnifications and the distribution of copper metal particle is indicated by the black spots within the COF nanosheets. The TEM images (Fig. 3b) show that the Cu NPs exhibit some variation in size (ranging from ∼8 nm to ∼20 nm, with an average size of ∼12 nm) and distribution, and some degree of agglomeration is present. By determining the d-spacing values, the presence of Cu and Cu2O nanoparticles has also been confirmed. The d-spacing values from the fringes are found to be 0.187 and 0.154 nm, respectively, suggesting the (200) and (220) planes of FCC Cu and Cu2O respectively [84,85]. Beside this, the support TR-PDA COF shows rippling sheet-like patterns in the TEM images (Fig. S3, Supporting Information), which are caused by π-π stacking among the subsequent COF layers [13]. Fig. S4 (Supporting Information) display photocatalyst’s electron image as well as elemental mapping pictures to verify the uniform distribution of copper (Cu), carbon (C), nitrogen (N), and oxygen (O), respectively. Additionally, elemental compositions of the TR-PDA COF (C, N and O) and the Cu@TR-PDA COF (C, N, O and Cu) are well-established based on the EDX (energy dispersive X-ray) analysis (Fig. S5 and Fig. S6, Supporting Information). The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of the TR-PDA COF and Cu@TR-PDA COF materials, illustrated in Fig. S7 (Supporting Information), was performed under inert environment (nitrogen) at temperatures between 30 and 800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C per minute to investigate the stability of the compound. The TGA plot (Fig. S7b, Supporting Information) indicates that the thermal degradation slows down between 80 and 370 °C and the degradation speeds up after reaching that certain temperature, which strongly suggesting that the Cu NPs embedded COF material is stable up to 370 °C. The loss of weight that is observed earlier than 370 °C is caused by the elimination of occluded solvent molecules and adsorbed gases inside the catalyst pores. In addition, the thermogravimetric investigation of TR-PDA COF support (Fig. S7a, Supporting Information) at the same temperature range displays lower thermal stability (312 °C) than Cu@TR-PDA COF. The chemical stability (Fig. S8, Supporting Information) of Cu@TR-PDA COF was also confirmed through solubility tests in strong acids (6 N HCl, 6 N H2SO4), strong bases (6 N NaOH), and boiled water. The material demonstrated excellent stability, with no significant changes in its chemical structures after 24 h. This was further confirmed by FTIR spectroscopy, which showed no alteration in the spectra of the as-synthesized Cu@TR-PDA COF after exposure to these harsh conditions. The high resolution XPS analysis was also carried out, as indicated in Fig. 4 , to gain additional insights regarding the valence state and chemical structure of the Cu@TR-PDA material. Fig. 4a presents the full scale XPS survey spectrum, indicating the existence of the characteristic peaks for C 1s, N 1s, O 1s, and Cu 2p in our sample. The deconvoluted C 1 s spectra (Fig. 4b) displays peaks with binding energies of 284.4, 285.8, and 288.0 eV, correspond to the CC/CC/C–H, C–N/CO, and CO, respectively [86]. Subpeaks present at 398.8 eV and 403.2 eV in the higher resolution N 1 s signal (Fig. 4c) are related to the nitrogen atoms associated with CN and NH bonds. The band at 400.0 eV is indicative of Cu−N attachment, which is caused by an interaction involving nitrogen atoms of enamines and copper atoms [87]. The XPS spectra of O 1s (Fig. 4d) shows four distinct peaks at 530.3, 530.8, 531.3 and 532.3 eV. Two peaks (Fig. 4d) are observed at 530.8 and 532.3 eV indicating CO and CO, which remain in the same positions as the TR-PDA COF (Fig. S9d, Supporting Information). However, after Cu modification, two additional peaks at 530.3 and 531.3 eV can be responsible for CuO and Cu2O, both of which are absent in the TR-PDA COF. The binding energies for Cu 2p, depicted in Fig. 4e, are positioned around 932.3 eV and 952.3 eV and can be attributed to Cu/Cu2O (Cu0/Cu+), which usually signify Cu2O species. Furthermore, the peaks situated at 934.4 and 954.5 eV, along with the adjacent satellite peaks at 940.4, 944.0, and 962.9 eV, also indicate the existence of CuO (Cu2+) [88]. Therefore, after deconvolution of the Cu 2p spectra, it is clear that the sample contains several chemical states of copper (Cu), associated with Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2 atomic orbitals. When the paramagnetic chemical state Cu2+ is present, it becomes challenging to specifically distinguish Cu0 and Cu+ species with the help of XPS because of the small difference in their binding energies [76]. Moreover, when exposed to air, Cu0 is rapidly transformed into Cu+ due to its susceptibility to oxidation [76]. Fig. S9 (Supporting Information) also illustrates the XPS spectrum of the support TR-PDA COF sample. The high-resolution C 1s signal of TR-PDA COF (Fig. S9b, Supporting Information) shows three peaks associated with the carbon atoms: CC/CC/CH (284.6 eV), CO/CN (286.6 eV), and CO (290.4 eV). Consequently, the peaks are positioned at around 399.9, 401.1, and 404.1 eV in the N 1 s spectroscopy are assigned to the CN, CN, and NH bonds, respectively (Fig. S9c, Supporting Information). To explore the light absorption capacity and optical properties, the UV-visible diffuse reflectance spectrum (obtained over the wavelength region of 200 to 800 nm) of the TR-PDA COF and Cu@TR-PDA photocatalyst, along with the Tauc plot of the Cu@TR-PDA photocatalyst, are presented in Fig. 5 a and 5b. Both synthesized materials (Fig. 5a) have distinctive wide absorption maxima that are positioned at around 382 nm and a small hump that is situated at 590 nm, indicating the presence of π-π*transition for heteroatom substituted conjugated framework and σ-σ* transition [89]. Beside this, comparing with the parent TR-PDA COF, the absorption edge of the UV–vis spectrum of Cu@TR-PDA photocatalyst is slightly shifted towards a longer wavelength (771 nm), indicating an interfacial interaction between Cu NPs and TR-PDA COF [90]. The shift in the absorption edge suggests that the Cu NPs influence the optical properties and electronic structure of the TR-PDA material. While a distinct Surface Plasmon Resonance (SPR) peak is not observed, the redshift indicates modification of the material's electronic structure by the Cu NPs incorporation. The intensity and shape of the SPR effect are influenced by factors such as the size, and distribution of the Cu nanoparticles [91]. In this case, the incorporation of Cu NPs within the COF resulted in a reduced SPR effect due to the variation in size and distribution of Cu NPs, and some degree of agglomeration. Beside this, some copper has oxidized to form Cu2O and CuO, which have different optical properties than metallic Cu and may reduce or alter the LSPR effect [92]. The TR-PDA COF itself exhibits strong absorption in the UV–vis region, which can even mask the relatively weak LSPR signal from the Cu NPs. The shortening band gap predicts superior visible-light harvesting and increased electron-hole pair generation. The Kubelka-Munk function is also employed to illustrate the Tauc plot (Fig. 5b) based on the UV-visible diffuse reflectance spectra. By varying the Kubelka-Munk function with photon energy (hν), the bandgap energies of the materials are calculated and the outcomes indicated that Cu@TR-PDA COF displays the direct and indirect band gap energy at around 2.14 and 1.76 eV, correspondingly (Fig. 5b). The direct band gap energy of TR-PDA COF (Fig. S10, Supporting Information) based on the Tauc plot is 2.35 eV, which is higher than the band gap energy of the Cu-incorporated COF (2.14 eV). The observed band gap narrowing, rather than a strong SPR effect, provides an indication of the change in material's electronic structure by the Cu NPs, affecting its light harvesting abilities. Additionally, the Cu@TR-PDA photocatalyst's emission spectrum (Fig. 5c) exhibits noticeable emission maxima at 488 nm (2.54 eV), which is considerably near to the estimated direct band gap value, proving that layered π-conjugated Cu@TR-PDA material is a direct band gap semiconductor. The recombination rate of photoinduced charge carriers was demonstrated using photoluminescence (PL) emission spectra (Fig 5c), which provides information about electron-hole recombination behaviour. As shown in Fig. 5c, the PL intensity of the Cu@TR-PDA material is significantly lower than that of TR-PDA COF indicates a reduced electron-hole recombination rate and a longer charge carrier lifetime [93–95]. The reduced recombination signifies improved charge separation, which is crucial for higher photocatalytic efficiency [96–98]. Therefore, the incorporation of Cu nanoparticles effectively mitigates the rapid electron-hole recombination observed in metal-free TR-PDA COF, leading to enhanced photocatalytic activity. Fig. 5d presents the cyclic voltammetry analysis of Cu@TR-PDA COF and the ground-state redox potential (E1/2) of this material is found to be 0.2 V vs Ag/AgCl. Fig. 5e illustrates the schematic diagram of the band structure for both TR-PDA COF and Cu@TR-PDA COF. The valence band spectra of both materials, obtained through XPS analysis, are shown in Fig S11 (Supporting Information), which provides the values of the valence band energies. For TR-PDA COF, the valence band (VB) energy is 1.29 eV vs. NHE, and the conduction band (CB) energy is −1.06 eV vs. NHE. In contrast, for Cu@TR-PDA COF, the valence band (VB) energy is 1.61 eV vs. NHE, and the conduction band (CB) energy is −0.53 eV vs. NHE. The electrochemical behaviour of the TR-PDA COF and Cu@TR-PDA photocatalyst (Fig. 6 ), such as electron transport and ionic diffusion kinetics, can be investigated using electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS). EIS analysis of both the materials were carried out in a frequency range from 100 kHz to 0.01 Hz, utilizing 0.1 M PBS as the electrolyte, a 10 mV AC amplitude, and a 5 mV constant potential. The semicircle observed in the high-frequency region represents the charge transfer resistance (Rct). TR-PDA COF displays a larger semicircle in the high-frequency region, indicating a higher Rct compared to Cu@TR-PDA, which exhibits a smaller semicircle. This small semicircle suggests that Cu@TR-PDA catalyst facilitates better charge transfer, crucial for efficient electrochemical performance [99,100]. In this EIS Nyquist plot, the linear portion of Cu@TR-PDA at low frequencies indicates the diffusion-controlled behaviour, associated with Warburg impedance. This suggests that Cu@TR-PDA exhibits more favourable ionic diffusion kinetics. The combination of lower Rct and improved diffusion characteristics represent superior electrochemical properties for Cu@TR-PDA compared to TR-PDA COF. 3.2 Photocatalytic activity 3.2.1 Synthesis of 2-hydroxybenzaldehyde by using Cu@TR-PDA as photocatalyst To find out the optimize reaction conditions for the production of 2-hydroxybenzaldehyde from phenol via the reduction of CO2, a number of screening tests were conducted using Scheme 3 as a model reaction. The experimental findings are summarized in Table 1 . The synthesis of 2-hydroxybenzaldehyde did not happen without light irradiation or without catalyst, respectively (Table 1, entries 1–2) using Phenol as starting material, K-O t Bu (2.0 mmol) as base in acetonitrile (CH3CN) under 1 atmospheric CO2 pressure. The reaction did not proceed even at low (0 °C) or high temperature (60 °C) without any light irradiation (Table 1, entries 3–4). These experimental findings confirmed that this synthetic procedure is undoubtedly a photocatalytic reaction. TR-PDA and Cu NPs alone did not provide any yield of the product (Table 1, entries 5 and 6). TR-PDA acted as the support, while Cu NPs served as the active sites. However, employing Cu@TR-PDA as a catalyst at 1 atm CO2 pressure and white light irradiation for 18 h resulted in 87 % conversion of phenol to 2-hydroxybenzaldehyde (Table 1, entry 7). These experimental findings therefore revealed that the improved photocatalytic activity of Cu@TR-PDA due to the synergistic interaction between the organic framework and the metal NPs. The PXRD analysis of Cu@TR-PDA COF exhibits good crystallinity and confirms the presence of CuO, Cu2O, and metallic Cu within the layered COF structure, plays a significant role in the synergistic effect by improving charge separation. Notably, the incorporation of Cu nanoparticles (NPs) does not disrupt the COF’s framework, as key functional groups remain intact, indicating good structural stability. This combination of crystallinity and stability enhances charge transfer and light absorption, improving photocatalytic performance. The interaction of Cu with the TR-PDA COF framework enhances the optical properties of the Cu@TR-PDA and narrows the material’s band gap, shifting its absorption spectrum into the visible light region, which improves light absorption and increases the generation of electron-hole pairs. Furthermore, as seen by the decreased PL intensity of Cu@TR-PDA material compared to TR-PDA COF, the Cu NPs are lowering recombination rates and extending carrier lifetimes. XPS data shows Cu-N interactions, which are essential for charge transfer and increase photocatalytic activity. The catalyst exhibited a reasonable yield of the intended product when selectively excited with blue LED light (Table 1, entry 8). Notably, 59 % of the intended product production was seen when the reaction mixture was illuminated by sunlight for 24 h (Table 1, entry 9). The conversion of phenol into 2-hydroxybenzaldehyde is obviously reliant on the type of solvent. Based on Table 1, it is evident that among the various solvents, acetonitrile proved to be the best solvent for the production of the 2-hydroxybenzaldehyde in comparison with low polarity solvent like THF, Toluene (Table 1, entry 10–12). Notably, no reaction has ever happened in an open environment without a CO2 balloon. (Table 1, entry 13). A notable increase in the intended product’s yield was observed during the photocatalysis process by changing the catalyst (Cu@TR-PDA) loading from 5 to 10 mg (Fig. 7 a). It was anticipated that 10 mg of catalyst would be adequate to convert phenol to 2-hydroxybenzaldehyde to the greatest extent possible, as adding more catalyst did not significantly enhance the yield of the final product. We investigated the effect of Cu NPs loading into the TR-PDA COF on the reaction yield (Fig. S13, Supporting Information) by varying the Cu NPs loading at 1.5 wt %, 2.5 wt %, 3.6 wt %, and 5 wt %. We observed that the maximum yield was achieved with a 3.6 wt % Cu NPs loading into the TR-PDA COF. Beyond this loading, the yield remained relatively constant, showing no significant improvement with higher loadings. A variety of organic and inorganic bases, including TEA, K2CO3, and K-O t Bu, were also investigated; and K-O t Bu proved to be the most effective for the desired transformation (Fig. 7b). In addition, the catalytic process was run for 12 h, turning on and off the light at every 2 h interval of time (Fig. 8 ). This study clearly demonstrated that product formation took place under irradiation of light and ceased in the absence of light. When compared to other proven catalytic CO2 fixation techniques, this light-modulated 2-hydroxybenzaldehyde synthesis process via CO2 reduction reaction offered an unprecedented level of control. After achieving the ideal reaction conditions, we moved on to concentrating on the several substrates scope of this photocatalytic protocol (Scheme 4 ) and the outcomes of these investigations are compiled in Table 2 . 2-hydroxybenzaldehyde was produced in reasonably good yield using Phenol as substrate (Table 2, entry 1). Among the different derivatives of phenols, Phenols containing electron donating (+I/+R effect) groups such as, methyl (-CH3) and methoxy (-OMe) at para position yielded a greater amount of the respective 2-hydroxybenzaldehydes (Table 2, entries 2 & 3) than that of phenols having electron-withdrawing groups (Table 2, entries 4 and 5). However, compared to phenols with para substituted electron withdrawing groups, phenols with electron-donating groups at the meta position showed a lower yield of the related 2-hydroxybenzaldehydes (Table 2, entry 6 & 7). Conversely, the comparatively low yield of the intended product was produced by the phenol derivatives with severely electron-withdrawing –NO2 group at para position (Table 2, entry 8). 3.2.2 Proposed photocatalytic reaction mechanism The obtained experimental results indicate that the reaction is solely driven by visible light irradiation. A probable catalytic pathway for the production of 2-hydroxybenzaldehyde from phenol in presence of CO2 under visible light irradiation is illustrated in Fig. 9 . The photocatalyst (Cu@TR-PDA) is first stimulated by visible light irradiation, which resulted in the formation of electron–hole pairs (e −–h +) at the photocatalyst surface. TEOA (widely known sacrificial electron donor) donates an electron to the excited photocatalyst, reducing the Cu catalytic sites while forming the highly reactive TEOA•+ radical cation. A proton (H⁺) from another TEOA molecule is then abstracted by this radical cation, creating the TEOA• carbon-centered radical and releasing a proton. In order to prevent back electron transfer (BET) and ensure the photocatalytic cycle's efficient continuation, the TEOA• radical further contributes electrons to intermediates. As a result, TEOA is essential for both proton abstraction and electron donation, which promotes the entire photocatalytic process. Then, electron transfer takes place from Cu sites to CO2, exciting the CO2 molecule absorbed on Cu@COF and forming CO2 ˙− intermediate. This CO2 ˙− intermediate contributes to the synthesis of formaldehyde (HCHO) through a combination of H + obtained from TEOA oxidation [101] and photogenerated electrons. The production of formaldehyde from CO2 reduction in presence of COF under visible light is in agreement with the existing reported literature [66,102]. In presence of strong base (K-O t Bu), the phenol is converted into phenoxide anion and it attacks to the more electron deficient carbonyl carbon of the formaldehyde through ortho position, resulting in the selective formation of 2-hydroxybenzaldehyde. It is important to note that while TEOA is critical in facilitating the reaction pathway by donating electrons and protons, it does not directly contribute to the final product formation, 2-hydroxybenzaldehyde. 3.3 Heterogeneity test During the photocatalytic reaction, a hot filtration procedure was applied to investigate the heterogeneous nature of the produced Cu@TR-PDA catalyst. Following 8 h of such observations, it was found that the process produced 55 % of 2-hydroxybenzaldehyde. The photocatalyst was then removed by filtering out, and the leftover filtrate was utilized to continue the process for 16 h without the catalyst. Notably, the yield of the desired product remained unchanged with no catalyst, suggesting that the reaction process stopped once the catalyst was isolated (Fig. S18a, Supporting Information). These findings revealed that the catalyst components were hardly ever leached out in the process of experiment, which indicates the synthesized Cu@TR-PDA catalyst is heterogeneous. 3.4 Recyclability of Cu@TR-PDA catalyst In order to investigate the recycling ability of the photocatalyst, the Cu@TR-PDA material was initially collected via centrifugation process after the end of the photocatalytic reaction then purified by washing thoroughly with plenty of ethanol and finally dried in a hot oven. The yield of the product obtained from the experiment using this recoverable catalyst is shown in Fig. S18b (Supporting Information), which also highlights no noticeable changes in the yield over six consecutive cycles. The above findings demonstrated the heterogeneity, robustness, reusability, and potential of Cu@TR-PDA COF catalyst for the photocatalytic reduction of CO2. Catalytic efficiency of the photocatalyst remained unchanged even after multiple regenerations. The recovered Cu@TR-PDA catalyst retained its structural as well as morphological characteristics, as evidenced by FTIR (Fig. S19, Supporting Information), FESEM (Fig. S20, Supporting Information), and HRTEM (Fig. S21, Supporting Information). The Cu@TR-PDA catalyst offers significant advantages in ortho-formylation of phenol than that of other reported catalysts (Table 3 ). TiCl4 catalyst having both corrosive and moisture-sensitive nature, required harsh conditions, including very low temperature and toxic solvent (such as dichloromethane), resulting in low yield of the desired products. Although Cu(NO3)2 and Ni(NO3)2 provided good yields, they required high-temperature reflux condition and long reaction time (10 h), leading to high energy consumption. The Fe3O4@SiO2∼urea/MgBr2 catalyst achieved excellent yields (97 %) at 70 °C; however, its synthetic method was complex, and it required high heating. In contrast, Cu@TR-PDA COF achieves good yields under mild conditions, specifically at room temperature, which reduces energy consumption compared to other catalysts. The reaction was conducted using 20 W white LED light as the energy source, providing a greener alternative to traditional heating techniques. Additionally, the use of readily available CO2 as a renewable C1 source further highlights the environmentally friendly nature of our approach. The heterogeneous nature of Cu@TR-PDA facilitates easy recycling process, also enhancing its sustainability. Cu@TR-PDA COF exhibits good selectivity for ortho-formylation, making it a promising alternative to other catalysts. 4 Conclusions In summary, we have fabricated a highly crystalline mesoporous copper nanoparticles loaded covalent organic framework (namely, Cu@TR-PDA) catalyst via simple hydrothermal method. The Cu@TR-PDA material is simple to synthesize and an efficient photocatalyst with outstanding photocatalytic properties for the production of 2-hydroxybenzaldehyde from phenol at room temperature in presence of CO2 under visible light. Moreover, the controlled analysis suggested that the catalytic reactions are completely dependent on light. After several recycling and reuse of the heterogeneous Cu@TR-PDA catalyst, there is no significant loss in its catalytic activity, and the morphology remains intact. The current study presents a novel strategy for producing value-added compounds from CO2 utilizing non-noble metal decorated COF and renewable solar energy. coredata.dc:description: Our study presents a novel synthetic approach for the visible-light-assisted photocatalytic production of 2-hydroxybenzaldehyde from phenol via CO2 reduction, using copper nanoparticles (Cu NPs)-incorporated two-dimensional covalent organic framework (TR-PDA COF) photocatalyst. The Cu@TR-PDA catalyst exhibited a low band gap energy (2.14 eV), enabling efficient visible light absorption and photocatalytic activity. Under optimized conditions, this catalyst achieved 87 % conversion of phenol to 2-hydroxybenzaldehyde under 20 W white LED light. The reaction was light-dependent and required a base. Mechanistic studies revealed that formaldehyde (HCHO), generated from CO2 photoreduction, served as a key intermediate, which reacted with phenol to form the desired product. Furthermore, the Cu@TR-PDA catalyst demonstrated excellent reusability over six cycles, and showed minimal metal leaching, confirming its heterogeneous nature. This work offers a promising strategy for the sustainable conversion of CO2 into valuable chemicals using a metal-based photocatalyst under visible light.
